lines.text: You begin to resent an actor if you always have to give him bad notices.

[after receiving Dickman's heart in a box]
It's him all right. Only Lionheart would have the temerity to rewrite Shakespeare!
Look, Devlin, when two people have the same motive to murder and one of them is still alive, who would you arrest?

[Devlin is examining a note on a gift-box]
"I am sorry to miss the meeting, but my heart is with you. George."
[he opens it and it contains George's bloody heart]
[repeated line]

[shocked]
Lionheart!
You drunken bum! You should treasure this opportunity to listen to a master, the world's greatest living actor!
I wonder if you'd look after Georgie? She gets so nervous in committee.
Take that revolting animal away from me!
[seeing a poster for Lionheart]
Saw him once. A very, uh, vigorous actor.
That's a good description.
Who hates you enough to kill two of your circle?
Critics are likely to make enemies, inspector. You can call it an occupational hazard.
But darling you, they're not going to start killing critics for giving bad notices are they?
Well, why not? A play fails; directors, writers, actors... careers ruined. Plenty of motivation there, I should think.
Take me home, I think I'm going to be ill.
Oh my God!
[looks at his dogs]
I think Georgina's going to faint!
Hello, Edwina. I thought it was you.
Well, the brilliant Peregrine Devlin. Wielder of the brutal aphorism, master of the killing phrase, my father's murderer.
That's a bit melodramatic, isn't it?
Forgive me. I forgot. It was your reverence and admiration that drove him to take his own life.
You don't understand.
I understand that the greatest actor of all time never earned your approval for one single performance. Never. Not one good review.
Look, Edwina, your father's body was never found.
My father is as good as under that granite!
[after sealing Larding's corpse in a wine barrel]
I wonder if he'll travel well?
I'm busy, Devlin.
Edwina, four of my collegues have been murdered. And their deaths relate directly to your father's last season.
If you were as imaginative in your reviews, Devlin, you'd be a better critic.
Officer! If I'm not mistaken, Mr. Psaltry is murdering his wife.
Oh... Thank you, Sir.
[Edward is still disguised as Butch]

[looking at the police officer]
Who's this great big beautiful thing with you? Is he yours?
Well, only just.
Come on, baby, let me get to it. Let me get at it, huh?
[the policeman, uncomfortable sits down]
You just sit there, baby, and relax, eh? She won't be long.

[as Butch]
Oh, I wish you'd let me do something camp with the colour, darling. Like flame with ash highlights.
These are very funny rollers, Butch.
Naughty, naughty! Don't touch, Butch knows best. They're something new from Gay Paree.
Nothing you can do will sway me from my original judgement.
Your judgement was ill considered and irresponsible.
It was neither. We gave the award to William Woodstock as your performances lacked originality.
this is your dish, Meredith Merridew? My Othello, one of the greatest performances in the history of the theatre?
Lionheart!
Alive and triumphant. And you thought me slain? Lionheart is immortal! He can never be destroyed, never!
Lionheart!
[gulps]
Impossible!

No, Larding! So, this critic slept through my Richard, did he? No doubt because you supped too much, you drunken hog. You may know that in Richard III, Clarence... and I do want you to try out for that part, Larding... was drowned in a vat of wine!
No!
[the tramps grab him and begin to drown him in a barrel]
Excellent, Larding, I'll make an actor of you yet.
[while stabbing Dickman to death]
Do you still say my Shylock was inadequate?
Now, let us see what that stupid cretin Mr Meredith Merridew had to say about my Titus Andronicus.
[reads]

Mr Lionheart's rendering of the role can only be described as villainous. Laid between the delicately underplayed performances of Miss Lillywhite as Lavinia and Miss Mole as Tamora, one is irresistibly reminded of a ham sandwich.
[pause]
My reputation.
Where could my doggies have got to?
Why, there they are both, baked in that pie. Whereof their mother daintily hath fed, eating the flesh that she herself hath bred.
Well, Larding, you said my Richard III cast such a spell on the audience...
[reads, disappointed]
"It put this reviewer in a deep sleep. And I awoke that I was spared attending the aging matinee idol's ranting and posturing." Well, let's see if we can get more rapt attention from you today.
[the door opens]
Dive, thoughts, down to my soul, here Clarence comes.
It's all right, sir. You're among friends, sir.
Thank you. I was beginning to get a bit nervous.
We were just rehearsing Troilus and Cressida. Specifically the scene where Hector, thinking he's among friends, is unexpectedly killed by them.
Lionheart, I came here for an interview, not a lecture on Shakespeare. Now tell me the amazing story of your resurrection.
It's a grave tale, Snipe. But I think you can rise to the occasion.
[Snipe is catapulted onto the stage, where the tramps begin to attack him]
I always admired you as a critic, Snipe. Your clever use of analogy and metaphor, plus you always strived to be complimentary. But not always complimentary.
Critics make mistakes, Lionheart. We're only human.
An opinion I find myself incapable of sharing.
[Lionheart is force-feeding Merridew his poodles]
Will you ever again ruin the reputation of an honest man?
No.
Have you learned your lesson?
Yes.
Can I be sure you will never again offend me?
Yes.
You're right. I can be sure.
[quoting Romeo and Juliet]
Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death, Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth, Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open, And, in despite, I'll cram thee with more food!
[first lines]
That damn editor's cut the best part of my review!
So I noticed, dear. You ought to have a chat with him.
My most provocative comment, too, where I said the leading lady attacked her role with both hands and strangled it to death.
You must admit I was most enthusiastic about your performance as Achilles.
Oh, yes. Yes, now that you mention it, I vaguely recall you wrote some review.

I remember it very well. I wrote, Edward Lionheart's Troilus and Cressida must be considered as a brilliant theatrical achievement, and his own performance as Achilles unsurpassed. Well, something of that sort.
A splendid review, my dear Snipe. Splendid. What else did you say?
More in the same vein.
Let me refresh your memory.
[reads]

...Achilles unsurpassed. This clearly is Lionheart's own view. That actor's oft-expressed desire for solitude is well known. He must derive much satisfaction in knowing that he is absolutely alone in his opinion of this lamentable production.
Lionheart!
Alive and triumphant. And you thought me slain? Lionheart is immortal!
You did kill Larding and the others didn't you?

How many actors have you destroyed as you destroyed me? How many talented lives have you cut down with your glib attacks? What do you know of the blood, sweat and toil of a theatrical production? Of the dedication of the men and the women in the noblest profession of them all? How could you know you talentless fools who spew vitriol on the creative efforts of others because because you lack the ability to create yourselves! No Devlin, no! I did not kill Larding and the others. PUNISHED them my dear boy, punished them. Just as you shall have to be punished.
Well get it over with then, just so you don't have to make me listen to that demented rubbish of yours. Go on, kill me then!
Was that dialogue from King Lear?
Yes. A remarkable performace. He was overacting as usual, but he knew how to make an exit.
Think about your daughter! Imagine what your madness is doing to her?
My daughter? Edwina?
[the hippie removes his beard and glasses to reveal he is Edwina]
I Return those duties back as are right fit. Obey you, love you, and most honour you
I will kill you when I am ready. Be it next week, next month perhaps next year. But first, I'm going to make you suffer in the same way you made me suffer!
You know, Butch, I'm very uncomfortable.

"Bring forth that sorceress condemned to burn." That's from Henry the Sixth, duckie, part one. It's a very interesting play, don't you agree, Miss Moon? Particularly that scene where Joan of Arc gets burnt at the stake.
[removing his disguise]
Though you may find our novel version a bit of a shock.
[she struggles, but he ties her down and heads towards an electric switch]
Place barrels of pitch upon the fatal stake, That so her torture may be shortened.
[he suddenly cranks the electric up]
Use no entreaty, for it is in vain. Break thou in pieces and consume to ashes, Thou foul accursed minister of hell!

[after feeding Meredith Merridew a pie made from his own pet poodles]
He just didn't have the stomach for it.
You... It's you! But you're dead!
No. Another critical miscalculation on you part. I am well. It is you who are dead.
[Edward is disguised as Butch, an effeminate hairdresser]
Hullo, I'm Butch. Hey, dishy, dishy hair. Can't wait to get my hands on it.
Do have some more!
Die, you strumpet!
Lionheart! What the hell do you want here?

[picking up the best actor award]
This. My just reward. The whole world knows it is mine by right. But you deliberately withheld it from me. You deliberately humiliated me in front of the press, my public and my peers. It was the culmination of your determined denial of my genius!
We denied you nothing...
For thirty years, the public has acknowledged that I was the master. And that, this year, my season of Shakespeare was the shining jewel in the crown of the immortal Bard.

[sotto voce, to Chloe Moon]
Quite insane!

[sotto voce, to Meredith Merridew]
He must be drunk.
But you, with your overweening malice, give the award to a twitching, mumbling boy who can barely grunt his way through an incomprehensible performance! No. No! It is mine!
